Electrodynamic

Pros & Cons
>Advantages: >" No power required >" Continuous indication >" Simple operation
>Disadvantages: >" Lower accuracy >" Parallax errors >" Limited features >

Measurement Technique Application Matrix
>
Technique >Voltage >Current >Resistance >Power >Frequency >Phase >Impedance >Quality >Cost
>
Moving Coil >Excellent >Excellent >Poor >No >No >No >No >Fair >Low
> Digital DMM >Excellent >Excellent >Excellent >Limited >Good >No >Limited >High >Medium
> Oscilloscope >Excellent >Good >Poor >Good >Excellent >Excellent >Good >High >High
> AC Bridges >Good >Good >Excellent >No >Limited >Good >Excellent >High >High
> Spectrum Analyzer >Good >Poor >No >Excellent >Excellent >Excellent >Good >High >High
> Network Analyzer >Good >Good >Good >Excellent >Excellent >Excellent >Excellent >High >Very High >
>
Legend: > Excellent/Good/Low > Fair/Limited/Medium > Poor/No/High >
>
Measurement Technique Selection Guidelines
>
Basic DC/AC Measurements >For routine measurements: >" Digital multimeter (0.1-0.5%) >" Cost-effective, versatile >" Suitable for most applications
>For portable applications: >" Analog meters (2-5%) >" No power required >" Trending indication >
Precision Measurements >For calibration labs: >" Precision multimeters (0.002%) >" Potentiometer methods >" Primary/secondary standards
>For R, L, C measurements: >" AC bridge methods >" LCR meters >" Network analyzers >
Dynamic Measurements >For waveform analysis: >" Digital oscilloscope >" Time domain analysis >" Transient capture
>For frequency analysis: >" Spectrum analyzer >" FFT analysis >" Harmonic distortion >
System Integration >For automated testing: >" Data acquisition systems >" Virtual instrumentation >" Computer control
>For industrial monitoring: >" Smart sensors >" Wireless networks >" Real-time monitoring >
>
Choose measurement techniques based on required accuracy, frequency range, cost constraints, and application requirements.
